Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. In this study, we show that the accessory protein Orf6 of SARS-CoV-2 is able to block nuclear import of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) and thereby impair the antiviral response. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. Here, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These results provide a molecular basis for the inhibitory effect of Zn2+ on proton channels. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. Meeting the food demand of this population will become increasingly challenging as the Earth’s climate continues to warm. Earlier studies suggest that once the optimum growing temperature is exceeded, mean crop yields decline and the variability of yield increases even if interannual climate variability remains unchanged. Herbivores are the primary agents of plant community assembly, and the diversity of herbivores is often thought to be a major driver of biodiversity. However, the extent to which different species of herbivores partition resources is largely unknown. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammalian herbivores in semiarid African savanna. Our results show that even closely related species of herbivores can differ substantially in their diets, and that even closely related species can differ substantially in their diets. These results suggest that the diversity of herbivores may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis, and many are financially fragile. Finally, many businesses plan to apply for the new federal loans, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is fatal within a few years after disease onset, and there is no treatment available to slow down the disease progression. Here we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-synuclein in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-synuclein, a hallmark of MSA. Our results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in MSA by limiting α-synuclein accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of this fatal neurodegenerative disorder.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected by a network of communication channels. The network is critical for the endothelium to control vascular function, but the nature of the communication channels has not been well understood. Here, we show that the communication network is highly efficient and that the cells are connected in a way that allows for rapid and robust communication between cells. These findings reveal the nature of the communication network and its role in the control of vascular function. The findings are important for understanding the control of vascular function and for the development of new therapies for cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are being used to understand the course of the pandemic, to inform public health policy, and to track the impact of the pandemic on the economy. This paper describes the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on the course of the pandemic, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The data are available for download at https://github.com/COVIDcast/covidcast-api. The data are also being used in a variety of applications, including in the COVIDcast project, which is described in more detail at https://github.com/COVIDcast.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is essential for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is only now being understood, and the potential for the microbiome to be manipulated therapeutically is being explored. The gut microbiome is also a dynamic ecosystem, and the composition of the microbiome is influenced by the host and the environment. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi, which are members of the gut microbiome, synthesize natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. In this study, we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is known to influence social behavior, directly influences social dominance in rats. We further show that this effect is mediated by the brain region nucleus accumbens, which is known to be involved in the regulation of social behavior. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in the regulation of social behavior and point to the nucleus accumbens as a potential target for the treatment of anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with desired behaviors is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the current design paradigm is limited by the availability of materials and the complexity of the structures. Here, we propose a strategy to synthesize and assemble materials into structures with desired behaviors. The proposed strategy is applicable to a wide range of materials and structures, and it can be extended to design and manufacture complex devices with specific behaviors.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development in mammals. In humans, the hemoglobin system is regulated by the expression of the alpha, beta, and gamma globin genes. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in the developing human erythroid system and that its expression is developmentally regulated. IGF2BP1 expression is reduced in the adult bone marrow and is increased in the fetal liver. In addition, IGF2BP1 expression is increased in the erythroid cells of a patient with a hemoglobinopathy. These results suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth, and the development of therapies that can control the growth of cancer cells is a major challenge. In this study, we show that the inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This sensitization is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we show that the combination of mTOR inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. These results suggest that the inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis may be a promising strategy for the treatment of cancer cells with mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway. (Read more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the prevention of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are effective, but they have some side effects. The aim of this study was to identify the mechanism of action of these drugs.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the Pacific Northwest. It was science-based, incorporated monitoring, and used adaptive management to address uncertainties. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test the influence of the NWFP on biodiversity. Our results show that the NWFP was effective in halting the decline of early-seral bird populations, but that older-forest–associated species continued to decline. The NWFP has not yet been successful in reversing the decline of older forests, which are critical for the conservation of biodiversity in the region.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is complex and depends on the stage of its expression.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles, including the origins of plant feeding, using a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and transcriptomes. Our results show that the evolution of beetles and angiosperms was linked, and that the evolution of plant cell wall-degrading enzymes was key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles.

Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may accelerate the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is a key to understanding the formation of the Earth and the evolution of the core. However, the formation process of the inner core is still controversial. In this study, we propose a two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core. The first step is the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron, which is the most stable phase at high pressure and temperature. The second step is the nucleation of the hcp phase from the bcc phase. This scenario can solve the paradox of the inner core nucleation.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as increased addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely powerful form of communication, and the human capacity for language is one of the defining features of modern humans. However, the brain mechanisms of language comprehension are only now beginning to be understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for language processing also predict the brain responses of human observers performing language comprehension tasks. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing is a fundamental mechanism in the brain’s language comprehension system.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is still an open question whether DL can be used in scientific computing, where the problems are often ill-conditioned. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. Our results imply a classification theory describing conditions under which stable NNs can be computed by an algorithm.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a unique case study in the study of human behavior. The pandemic’s early stages are marked by a period of exponential growth, which is a well-known phenomenon. However, the scientific community is increasingly concerned that the public’s inability to understand exponential growth is a major factor in the pandemic’s spread. This paper discusses the origins of this concern, the classic psychological experiment that is the basis for it, and the flaws in the experiment’s design.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which are responsible for different forms of the disease. The two species have diverged from a common ancestor, but the extent of their divergence and the mechanisms that led to their current evolutionary status are not well understood. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis from a patient in Mexico and compared it with that of M. leprae. Our results suggest that the two species are remarkably conserved and that they are still able to cause disease. This study provides a better understanding of the evolution of leprosy bacteria and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of leprosy. (Show more)

Entanglement and entropy are key concepts standing at the foundations of quantum and statistical mechanics. Although the unitary time evolution ensuing from a pure state maintains the system at zero entropy, local properties at long times are captured by a statistical ensemble with nonzero thermodynamic entropy, which is the entanglement accumulated during the dynamics. Therefore, understanding the entanglement evolution unveils how thermodynamics emerges in isolated systems. Alas, an exact computation of the entanglement dynamics was available so far only for noninteracting systems, whereas it was deemed unfeasible for interacting ones. Here, we show that the standard quasiparticle picture of the entanglement evolution, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We thoroughly check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that requires the development of a vaccine that is safe, effective, and broadly protective. Here, we describe the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, which is currently in clinical development. The vaccine is highly attenuated, has a large-scale manufacturing potential, and is protective in a relevant hamster model. These properties, coupled with the fact that it is a live vaccine, support its potential use in mass vaccination programs. This is the first report of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, which is a promising candidate for the development of a vaccine against COVID-19. (Show more)

Plague is a disease with a long history of human suffering and death. It is also a disease that can be transmitted by multiple transmission pathways, including the spread by rodents, the spread by fleas, and the spread by direct contact between humans. In this study, we use a mathematical model to investigate the historical spread of plague in Europe. We find that the spread of plague in Europe was predominantly spread by human ectoparasites, including fleas and lice, during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries). This finding challenges the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats.

The role of TRAP1 in mitochondria has been the subject of intense investigation, but the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells has been unclear. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin filaments are the main components of the cytoskeleton, which is essential for cell shape and movement. They are also the main targets of the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins. ADF/cofilin are the central regulators of actin filament disassembly. However, how it does so in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we monitor and quantify the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations by using single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques, coupled to microfluidics. We find that local curvature favors severing, while tension surprisingly has no effect on cofilin binding and weakly enhances severing. Remarkably, we observe that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon cofilin binding. We find that this ADF/cofilin-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. A consequence of this mechanism, which we verify experimentally, is that cross-linked filament networks are severed by cofilin far more efficiently than nonconnected filaments.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in place of glucose in processed foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and food-seeking behavior.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, and from the east to the west. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestries, with a recent settlement of the island. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the colonization of Madagascar happened independently from Africa and Asia. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar, which is a unique case in the world.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, in which people experience the same emotions without their awareness. This work suggests that in-person interaction is not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is widespread and has been shown to impact mRNA stability, translation, and other processes. Here, we show that the presence of one of the most common modifications in coding regions, pseudouridine (Ψ), can also impact translation. We find that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA can have a significant impact on the translation of the mRNA, and that the presence of Ψ in coding regions may be a mechanism by which the ribosome can be influenced in the course of translation. This may have important implications for the regulation of translation. (Show more)

The feeling that the things one does in life are worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social engagement, and behavioral and lifestyle factors. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of aquatic life is thought to have driven the evolution of larger body sizes in mammals. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The ability of rhinovirus to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature has been attributed to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. Here, we show that the expression of antiviral defense genes in response to rhinovirus infection is higher at the cool temperature than at the core body temperature. We also show that the expression of antiviral defense genes is dependent on the MAVS protein, which is a key signaling adaptor of the RIG-I–like receptors. These findings demonstrate that in mouse airway cells, rhinovirus replicates preferentially at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These results have implications for understanding the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication in the human upper respiratory tract. (truncated)

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. In this study, we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense the presence of surfaces. This mechanism is essential for the regulation of virulence and biofilm formation.

The use of pesticides in agriculture is a major cause of water pollution. However, the extent of the problem is not well understood because of a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. This study provides a comprehensive metaanalysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2 is of great interest. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in 33.2% of free-living white-tailed deer in Iowa. We also show that the number of positive deer samples increased by 82.5% following the onset of the deer hunting season. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study highlights the need for a better understanding of the role of animals in the spread of the virus.

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a worldwide public health crisis. The disease is thought to be driven by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau, which are deposited in the brain and are known to trigger an immune response. However, the earliest events in AD are poorly understood, and it is unclear whether the immune response is initiated by the deposition of Aβ or by the intraneuronal accumulation of the toxic species. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cells in the brain, are the primary source of inflammatory factors in the brain, even in the absence of Aβ deposition. These findings have important implications for the development of new AD therapies, since they suggest that targeting the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ may be a more effective strategy for treating the disease.

The domestic chicken is today one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. We present the results of a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which demonstrate that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant in the fourth–second centuries B.C.E. We further show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe predates the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century.

The accumulation of RNA molecules capped with dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress conditions has been shown to be a mechanism for bacterial adaptation. However, the mechanism by which this capping occurs is not fully understood. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to remove the cap from capped RNAs, is the predominant decapping enzyme in Escherichia coli cells experiencing disulfide stress. We demonstrate that RppH preferentially removes Np4-capped RNAs over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts, and that the unique manner in which capped substrates bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack. These findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress conditions. (Show more)

Sepsis is a major cause of death worldwide. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs in sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that the administration of citrulline, a dietary amino acid, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation and decreasing the expansion of Treg and MDSCs in a mouse model of sepsis. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy to improve the immune response in sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature, where systems with a simple underlying structure exhibit complex behavior. SOC systems are characterized by a critical state, where the system is neither too slow nor too fast, and by self-organized criticality, where the system is able to maintain a critical state. The sandpile model is the first and archetypical model of SOC. In this paper, we study the sandpile model in the limit of large number of sites. We show that the model exhibits a scaling limit with SOC behavior. This is a continuous model, in contrast to all known models of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and chemical inertness. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control, and its bandgap is difficult to tune. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly, and its bandgap can be tuned continuously, by applying strain. This opens up opportunities to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond, and to tailor its properties for specific applications.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest in the pharmaceutical industry. The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest in the pharmaceutical industry. Here, we report the solution structure of a unique antifungal peptide, which is a member of the highly diverse NCR peptide family. The structure of the peptide is largely disordered and dynamic. The peptide exhibits potent antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The mode of action of the peptide is unique and different from that of other known antifungal peptides. The results of this study provide a basis for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the proteome of the sperm changes substantially after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the sperm proteome, and that these contributions are critical for sperm viability. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community, as it provides a model for the study of sperm–FRT interactions in other species.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, to control bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain in VWF binds to the platelet receptor glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) and that force application switches the A1 to a second state with faster on-rate. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD. The results also suggest that the A1 domain is a promising target for the treatment of VWD.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the role of viruses in human health has only recently been explored. This study is the first to provide a comprehensive database of viruses from human-associated samples. The database, which is freely available, contains over 45,000 unique virus taxa, with over 100 million viral sequences. The database is also used to identify over 2,200 virus–disease associations. This study is a major step forward in understanding the role of viruses in human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the ACI process is complex and difficult to be observed. Here, we introduce a new technique to observe the aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The origin of life is one of the most fundamental questions in science. The Earth’s surface temperature at the time of origin is a key factor in the origin of life. Here, we show that the surface temperature of the Earth decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations.

Ion channels are the key regulators of ion flow and cell function. The K+ channel KCNK17, also known as BK, is a large-conductance calcium-activated potassium channel that is important for cardiac function. It is normally open and inactivated by C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation.

Malaria parasite invasion of the red blood cell (RBC) is a complex process that requires the parasite to overcome a number of physical barriers. Here, we show that the erythrocyte-binding antigen EBA175 alters the physical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding suggests that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion, a concept that has not been considered in the past.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and chemical inertness. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control, and its bandgap is difficult to tune. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly, without phonon instability, by applying strain. We also show that the bandgap can be tuned by strain, and that the bandgap can be made direct, without phonon instability. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in humans. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have important implications for the development of strategies to reduce the impact of influenza virus infection in the context of low humidity. This article is protected by copyright. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and sentences at the top. This paper provides the first direct evidence for such a structure in the human brain.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major regulator of development and tissue homeostasis. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are regulated differently, which may be important for tissue-specific regulation of the pathway. This is an important finding that may be important for the design of future studies on redundant genes in vertebrates.

Obesity is a major health problem, and the search for the neural circuits involved in the regulation of food intake is a major area of research. Here we describe a circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria is a key technology for sustainable agriculture. Here, we have developed a system for the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley.

The Peruvian Amazon is one of the most deforested regions in the world. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, early deforestation alerts rarely reach the most directly affected communities in time to deter deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals are able to hear the world around them, but how they do this is very different from each other. In this paper, we show that the spider can hear the world around it without being constrained by the size of its body.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to claim lives and disrupt economies worldwide. The development of vaccines is a critical step in the fight against the pandemic. Here we report the design and construction of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is suited for large-volume production. The engineered protein exhibits high-affinity binding to ACE2, and antibodies raised against the engineered protein exhibit heterotypic binding to the RBD from two recently reported variants of concern. Presentation of the engineered RBD on a designed VLP also reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the engineered RBD protein may be a useful tool for vaccine development and for the development of other vaccines against emerging viruses. This engineered protein may also be useful for the development of diagnostics. The engineered protein may also be useful for the development of diagnostics.

The role of ALK in the development of neural crest-derived tissues is well established. Here, we show that the zebrafish ALK homologue, DrLtk, is activated by the zebrafish ALKALs. We further show that the loss of DrLtk and the three zebrafish ALKALs causes distinct patterns of iridophore loss in zebrafish larvae and that the loss of DrLtk and the three zebrafish ALKALs causes a complete loss of iridophores in zebrafish. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of ALK/LTK family receptors in neural crest development. This finding is of importance for the understanding of the role of ALK in the development of neural crest-derived tissues in general.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it, Yersinia pestis, has been responsible for some of the most devastating pandemics in human history. The earliest Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Neolithic period in Eurasia have revealed key evolutionary steps that led to its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague, which will be of great interest to the scientific community. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. We find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election.

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of annual cropping systems on grasslands is a major source of SOC loss. Here, we show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage and the amount of SOC in the more stable mineral fraction. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester SOC and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural practices.

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. Using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world, we ranked the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. Validating the risk assessment, the top 12 were known zoonotic viruses. The SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for visitation. In some plants, the color of the nectar is red, which is thought to be an adaptation to attract vertebrate pollinators. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also show that the red color of the nectar is attractive to the most likely vertebrate pollinators of this plant. Our work suggests that the red color of the nectar is a convergent trait, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation.

We present a study of the genetic structure of a group of women from Bavaria in southern Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 7th centuries AD. Our results indicate that they had a very high genetic diversity, which is not only due to the small size of the population. In addition, we found that some of them had a genetic ancestry that is not found in modern Europeans. This indicates that the genetic structure of the population was not only shaped by the migration of men, but also by the migration of women. Finally, we found that many of the functional variants that are associated with positive selection in modern humans were already at modern-like frequencies in the population studied. This indicates that the processes that shaped the genetic structure of the population were already in motion at the time of the study.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. We describe the use of a cloud-based metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a resource-scarce setting. We demonstrate the ability to detect a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. We also show that mNGS can be used to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings. This approach can be used to better understand the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and to deploy rapid public health response. This work is important for the global community, as it demonstrates the feasibility of mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. The human genome is replicated in the nucleus of the cell. The process is complex and requires the cooperation of many proteins. One of the most important proteins is proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). PCNA is a sliding clamp that allows DNA polymerase δ to replicate the lagging strand template. We have developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the PCNA-pol δ holoenzyme. The results indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This behavior is essential for the accurate replication of the lagging strand template.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the laboratory, the evolution of life can be studied in a controlled setting, and the results can be compared with the conditions that existed on the early Earth. In this paper, we describe the evolution of an RNA polymerase that can replicate and synthesize functional RNA molecules in the absence of proteins. This work is a step toward the reconstruction of the origins of life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex and the treatment is still in the early stage. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, is effective in the treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is expected that this study will provide a reference for the treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its role in the biology of fungi is poorly understood. Here we demonstrate that the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus binds copper and has a role in the regulation of intracellular copper pools. Xanthocillin-derived isocyanide products have antimicrobial properties, and copper is required for the activity of xanthocillin-derived products against a variety of pathogenic microbes. These results suggest that the xanthocillin BGC may be a source of fungal natural products that regulate copper homeostasis and mediate interactions with competing microbes. The existence of the xanthocillin BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a role for eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides a model for the evolution of fungal natural products that regulate metal homeostasis and may have implications for the development of antifungal strategies. (Show more)

Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2 that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a drill sample of laminated mudstone (Buckskin) at the base of the Gale crater sequence on Mars is significant because it is the first detection of this mineral in a sedimentary environment. The presence of tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in the sample is consistent with the sediment source being the crater wall/rim/central peak. The amorphous silica, mixed-cation salts, and oxides are products of multiple aqueous fluid infiltrations. The diagenesis of the sample is consistent with the presence of a “Lake Gale” environment. The diagenesis of the sample is also consistent with the presence of a “Lake Gale” environment.

Frost events are a major threat to plants and animals in the temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not adapted to the new conditions. Our findings have important implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a subset of CD4+ T cells that play a central role in the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the development of disease is not well understood. Here, we show that the development of colitis requires the dual action of Th17 cells: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These results have important implications for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is thought to be driven by the toxic effects of these mutations. We have developed a method to convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced neuronal progenitor cells and subsequent differentiation into astrocytes. This enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This approach will accelerate the development of therapeutics for ALS. The gut microbiota of arthropods is critical for the health of the host, but the role of the microbiota in the life cycle of infectious agents is poorly understood. Here, we show that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the gut microbiota of the vector, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the tick. We demonstrate that the bacterium induces the tick to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the integrity of the gut microbiota and the peritrophic matrix, which is a critical obstacle for the colonization of the pathogen. These data provide a molecular understanding of how a pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This knowledge will be critical for the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The short tail of birds is thought to have evolved from the long tail of basal birds. However, the early evolution of the short tail is poorly understood because of the limited known diversity of early branching short-tailed birds. Here, we describe a basal short-tailed bird, Jinguofortis, from the Early Cretaceous of China. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal short-tailed birds and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding the evolution of the avian tail.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand its behavior. One of the most difficult aspects of the climate system is the role of water vapor. Water vapor is a key component of the atmosphere, but it is difficult to understand its role because it is difficult to measure. Here, we show that water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This ability is important for the animals’ survival, as it allows them to adapt to their environment. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the leading cause of cancer death. The identification of factors that promote the development of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) is important for the development of new therapeutic strategies. Here, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn promotes the development of BCSCs. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment is a longstanding controversy in codicology. Here, we present a method to determine the animal origin of parchment, which can be used to settle this debate.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. Understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics depends on an accurate and precise age model. U-Pb zircon dates for five volcanic ash beds from the Global Stratotype Section and Point for the Permian-Triassic boundary at Meishan, China, define an age model for the extinction and allow exploration of the links between global environmental perturbation, carbon cycle disruption, mass extinction, and recovery at millennial timescales. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract. IBD is a complex disease with a high incidence and a high rate of recurrence. The pathogenesis of IBD is complex and not fully understood. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in the pathogenesis of IBD. RORα is a transcription factor that can regulate the expression of genes involved in the inflammatory response. We found that RORα plays a role in the control of the inflammatory response by regulating the expression of NF-κB target genes. Our results suggest that RORα could be a potential target for the treatment of IBD. This study provides a new perspective for the treatment of IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein in complex with the human receptor, angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2), at 8.3 Å resolution. The structure of the spike in complex with ACE2 reveals a range of conformational states, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. The structure of the spike in complex with ACE2 may aid in the development of therapeutics and vaccines.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We project that the pandemic will result in a decline in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, the largest decline since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity are two central properties of atoms, which can be seen as the first- and second-order chemical potentials. We show that these properties decrease with pressure, consistent with pressure-induced metallization. Furthermore, we show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become electron acceptors. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of wildfires, but the impact on the global carbon cycle is poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, as caused by socioeconomic development, can reduce fire activity, which in turn can reduce warming. Our results highlight the importance of human activities in driving fire regimes, and the potential for mitigating climate change.

The provision of nutrients to specific microbes in the gut is a widespread strategy used by animals to control the activities of their microbiota. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to control the activities of a symbiotic bacterium in the squid Euprymna scolopes. We show that the glycan is provided to the squid only at night, when the symbiotic organ is at its most active. We also show that the glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is required for the maintenance of a normal symbiont population level. Finally, we show that catabolism of the glycan is required for a periodic acidification of the symbiotic organ, which increases the level of oxygen available to the symbionts. This study provides a direct link between the provision of nutrients and the activities of the microbiota. We propose that other hosts may similarly regulate the activities of their gut microbiota through the strategic provision of specific nutrients, whose catabolism modulates conditions like pH or anoxia in the habitat of the microbiota. Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify topics in a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The Black Death, the most devastating epidemic in human history, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. Here, we show that the climate in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe was favorable for the spread of the disease, and that the bacterium was reintroduced into Europe on multiple occasions. We find no evidence for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. Our results suggest that the Black Death was the consequence of multiple introductions of the disease, which were facilitated by climate change.

Asteroids are a group of organisms that are found in the ocean and on the seafloor. They are characterized by a lack of a hard exoskeleton and a dependence on viruses for their survival. In the past few years, a disease has emerged that is killing asteroids in large numbers. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is associated with the disease.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults. Despite advances in treatment, the survival rate of AML patients remains poor. The identification of the leukemic stem cell as the cause of relapse and the only source of resistance to therapy has led to the development of targeted therapies directed against these cells. Here, we show that antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) are effective in the treatment of AML. This is the first report of the use of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based therapy. Our results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach may be applicable to other cancers as well. (truncated)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, and from the east to the west. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestry, with a recent settlement of the island. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia happened independently. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar, which is a unique case in the world.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation antibody therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the backbone of the agricultural sector, providing information on the status of crops at the local level. However, their information is often not used in agricultural decision-making. We show that the information provided by crop experts can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. We demonstrate that the information provided by crop experts can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the time constant of the adaptation process. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the time constant of the adaptation process. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the time constant of the adaptation process.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest. However, despite decades of research, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most fundamental events in the evolution of life. It is also one of the most studied, but the underlying molecular mechanisms remain poorly understood. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings have implications for the understanding of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes and their role in the origin of life.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the impact of climate change on water security. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for water resource managers, policy makers, and the general public in SSA and beyond. The results are also relevant for other regions that are vulnerable to multiyear droughts, such as the Mediterranean.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the study of materials. However, the conditions under which they form are not fully understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this anthropogenic quasicrystal, with its precise time of creation, provides a unique window into the conditions under which quasicrystals form.

The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in (bacterio)chlorophylls is one of the most important reactions in photosynthesis. The mechanism of this reaction is unknown, and the only known enzyme, BchE, is O2 sensitive. Here we show that the O2-dependent cyclase in oxygenic phototrophs is composed of three classes, and that the evolution of the cyclase is linked to the evolution of oxygenic photosynthesis.

Neuroinflammation is a major contributor to neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is regulated by a variety of signaling pathways, and one of the most important signaling molecules is apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1). In this study, we found that ASK1 plays a critical role in the development of neuroinflammation in experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), an animal model of MS. We also found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the development of neuroinflammation, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the later stage of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a better understanding of the role of neuroinflammation in EAE and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuroinflammation-related diseases.
