The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability that a dry year will also be extremely warm has increased in recent decades. This finding is consistent with the hypothesis that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability that dry years are also hot.

Autism is a complex disorder with a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for mapping out the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. It also provides a potential target for the development of a behavioral intervention for autism. This study is expected to contribute to the development of a behavioral intervention for autism.

The news media are a powerful force in shaping public opinion, and the content of the news is a key factor in determining public opinion. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment that examines the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that this is indeed the case, and that the extent of this negativity bias varies considerably across individuals. These results help explain the prevalence of negative news content around the world, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis. In this study, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel that result in a spectrum of phenotypes, including hematological abnormalities. These data expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel and suggest new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the endocytic pathway and that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. These findings may help to reduce the risk of viral spillover from bats to humans. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and thus one-carbon metabolism is a critical metabolic pathway. Here we show that the one-carbon donor pathway is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer.

The presence of coaggregating proteins in the inclusions of mutant superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), TDP-43, and Fused in Sarcoma (FUS) is a characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the motor neuron disease amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). We show that the presence of coaggregating proteins in ALS is not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the coaggregating proteins are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. These results suggest that the presence of coaggregating proteins in ALS results from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons. Thus, the presence of coaggregating proteins in ALS may be a marker for a specific set of proteins that are prone to aggregation in motor neurons. This may be a useful marker for the identification of the specific proteins that are involved in the pathogenesis of ALS. (Read more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants are poorly known, and the ecological conditions under which they originated are still debated. Here we present a detailed study of Montsechia, a very early flowering plant from the Cretaceous. The study of this plant, which is about 100 y old, shows that it was an aquatic plant, similar to Ceratophyllum, and that it was one of the first flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is of great interest, as it can shed light on the origin of new diseases and the evolution of drug resistance. Here we present the first ancient viral sequences, which show that the human parvovirus B19 has been circulating for a long time. We also show that the recombination event that formed the current B19V genotype 2 occurred at a time when the human population was at its highest level in the last 120 thousand years.

Sea level around the world has been rising steadily over the last 25 y, and this rate is accelerating. This acceleration is due to the combined effects of climate change and the Earth’s internal deformation. We find that the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2. This implies that, if the rate of climate-change–driven acceleration continues, global mean sea level could rise 65 ± 12 cm by 2100 compared with 2005. This estimate is in agreement with the 5th Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.

Pain is a major public health problem, and the elderly are more likely to report pain than are those in midlife. However, in America today, the elderly report less pain than those in midlife. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that pain is not declining with age in America today, and that the elderly are not less likely to report pain than are those in midlife. Instead, pain is increasing with age for all adults, and the increase is greater for those with less education. Tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, and the erosion of working-class life may be a major contributor to this trend.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe human coronavirus that has a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a nucleotide analog that has been shown to inhibit SARS-CoV replication in vitro and in vivo. Here, we show that remdesivir is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection, and that it can be used both prophylactically and therapeutically. These data support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial setting, and also suggest that it may be effective against other coronaviruses. This is an important step forward in the development of antiviral treatments for MERS and other coronaviruses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The provision of nutrients to specific microbes in the gut is a widespread strategy used by animals to regulate the activities of their gut microbiota. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the activities of the symbiont in a bioluminescent squid–Vibrio symbiosis. This glycan is only provided to the host at dusk, when the squid is preparing to produce light. We show that the glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is able to maintain a normal symbiont population level only until the symbiotic organ reaches maturity. Finally, catabolism of the glycan by the symbionts is also required for a periodic acidification of the adult crypts each night, which increases the level of oxygen available to the symbionts. This study provides a direct link between the provision of nutrients and the regulation of the activities of gut microbiota. (Show more)

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can interfere with the accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this work, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcription of a lacZ reporter gene. We found that the transcription of the lacZ reporter gene is stalled at the EtdT lesions. The stalling is relieved by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop).

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. The food system is a major contributor to environmental degradation and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food choices of the world’s population are a key driver of this problem. This study shows that it is possible to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals served in a catering environment by 60% or more, with minimal impact on overall sales. This is a significant contribution to the sustainability of the food system.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to the surfaceome of a panel of six oncogene-expressing breast epithelial cells, and find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We complement the surfaceome data with glycoproteomics, and find that each oncogene has a different glycoproteome, but that the glycoproteome is also harmonized by common biological themes. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a first step toward a systems-level understanding of the cell surface in cancer.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of over 300,000 Americans. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that may be important for immune evasion. This work provides a foundation for understanding the molecular basis of the disease and the development of therapeutics and vaccines. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the hypoxic induction of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. These effects, except for the increased expression of CRF itself, could all be blocked by pretreatment with an antagonist of the CRF receptor CRFR1. We also show that, in cultured primary astrocytes, hypoxic induction of CRFR1 and AQP4 is mediated by cAMP/PKA. Finally, using CHO cells transfected with CRFR1+ and AQP4+, we show that transfected CRFR1+ contributes to edema via transfected AQP4+. These results provide a molecular understanding of the mechanisms underlying hypoxic induction of edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of cerebral edema. The scientific enterprise is in the midst of a revolution. The amount of data being generated is growing exponentially. The complexity of the statistical methods being used to analyze these data is also growing exponentially. This paper addresses a fundamental challenge in this new era: How do we properly assess the strength of associations in the face of this explosion of data and complexity of methods? We describe a set of methods for addressing this challenge. These methods are based on the principle that we should set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find.

The development of vascular networks is a complex process that requires the cooperation of multiple transcription factors. In this study, we identified a transcription factor, Ets variant 2 (ETV2), that is essential for the development of vascular endothelial cells. ETV2 is a member of the ETS family of transcription factors, which are known to play important roles in the development of hematopoietic cells. Here, we demonstrate that ETV2 is also essential for the development of vascular endothelial cells. Our study provides a better understanding of the development of vascular networks in the human body. It also provides a new strategy for the generation of vascular networks for the treatment of vascular diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are a family of transmembrane receptors that are involved in a wide range of biological processes. In the past decade, two additional RTKs have been identified that are not part of the canonical RTK family: ALKAL1 and ALKAL2. These two proteins are important for the development of the zebrafish eye and the skin. Here, we show that ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 are ligands for ALK and Ltk, respectively. We also show that ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 are essential for the development of the zebrafish eye and the skin. These results establish ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 as physiological ligands for ALK and Ltk, respectively. This finding has important implications for the understanding of the role of ALK and Ltk in development and cancer.

β-cell dysfunction is a major molecular basis for type 2 diabetes (T2D). In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function. STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. STING is down-regulated in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza A viruses are responsible for an annual influenza epidemic and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. We also show that this interaction favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with the development of atherosclerotic lesions. The atheroprone flow environment is a critical factor in the development of atherosclerotic lesions. However, the mechanisms underlying the disturbed flow regulation of the atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions are not fully understood. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by the atheroprone flow environment is a critical factor in the development of the atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow regulation of the atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study also provides a potential target for the development of athero-protective drugs. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of the Earth system, but they can also be a threat to human communities and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that human-started wildfires disproportionately occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should be a focus of United States policy.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel that mediates the perception of natural repellents. This study provides a molecular basis for the evolution of natural repellents in arthropods and the conservation of biodiversity. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with fetal abnormalities and neurological complications, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral reefs are in the midst of a mass bleaching event, which is driven by anthropogenic warming of the oceans. The breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is a major consequence of this breakdown, but the underlying causes remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic state of the coral host is a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, which in turn contributes to the breakdown of the symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. In this study, we show that the loss of a tumor suppressor, which leads to the formation of intestinal tumors, results in the dysregulation of the microbiome and the activation of a regenerative response. We identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for the development of therapies that target the tumor microenvironment. They also provide a model for the study of the role of the microbiome in the development of intestinal tumors. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Chemotherapy is an important treatment for patients with breast cancer. However, the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and some patients do not respond to treatment. In this study, we show that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that the expression of ROR1 enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and to reestablish tumor growth in mice. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (truncated)

The timing of the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is one of the most important questions in the history of the Earth system. Here we show that the start of deglaciation was linked to a series of volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and climate changes similar to those associated with modern ozone depletion over Antarctica.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of animal protein, recreation, and commerce in many regions of the world. However, they are often overlooked in assessments of global fisheries. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our data can be used to improve fishery management and protect biodiversity in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The ability to regenerate is a fundamental property of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, the regenerative capacity is limited, and regeneration is often unsuccessful after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult CNS. This discovery is important because it provides a platform for the discovery of factors that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome. It is also the target of many human diseases. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination in the genome of a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that the distribution of recombination is highly similar to that in the genomes of other eukaryotes, including yeast and mice. This suggests that the general pattern of recombination initiation in the genome may be ancient and conserved.

The brain is a dynamic organ, and the study of its resting state is a fundamental step in understanding its functional organization. Here, we show that the resting state organization of the human brain can be identified and validated by combining functional MRI and metabolic imaging. This approach provides a direct measure of the brain’s resting organization, which can be used to study the normal organization of the brain and to identify alterations in the brain in disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for the stability and translation of mRNA. The existence of other 5′ modifications in eukaryotes is unknown. Here we report the discovery of a 5′ NAD+ cap structure in nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. This is the first example of a 5′ modification that is not a cap structure.

The study of the mechanisms of the metabolic memory phenomenon, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT), has been hampered by the lack of a suitable model. We used a unique model, the Diabetes EDIC Study, to show that DNA methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years in people with diabetes and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

In this study, we show that the expression of the protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is associated with poor prognosis in patients with triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). We also show that FSIP1 is associated with drug resistance in TNBC cells. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a complex disease with a high prevalence and a high social and economic impact. The etiology of the disease is still unknown, but it is thought to be multifactorial. The gut microbiota has been shown to be involved in the development of psychiatric disorders, which suggests the existence of a gut–brain axis in these disorders. In the present study, we found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The production of volatile compounds in plants is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of factors. In this study, we identify a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of volatile compounds in tomato fruit and will be of interest to the scientific community interested in the production of volatile compounds in plants. We show that the impacts of global warming on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are dependent on the thermal tolerance of species. We also show that the impacts of biodiversity loss on ecosystem functioning are likely to be exacerbated by environmental warming. Our results highlight the importance of considering the thermal tolerance of species when assessing the impacts of climate change on biodiversity and ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains a large population of neurons that fire in a place-dependent manner, and the organization of these neurons is thought to be critical for navigation. However, the anatomical and functional organization of this population is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that the organization of place cells is different from that of other neurons in MEC. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of place cells in the brain that guides navigation. This view will be useful for understanding the mechanisms of navigation.

Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a variety of environmental and internal signals. In this study, we show that flowering of the host is required for flowering of the parasite. This is an example of a unique means of flowering regulation, which is likely to be found in other parasites.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We also seek to understand others, and we do so by reading their minds. In this paper, we show that the mind of another person can be read by the speed at which it responds to us.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is also responsible for maintaining the heart rate in the absence of external stimuli. The SAN is composed of a small number of cells, and the mechanisms that regulate the number of cells and their activities are not well understood. Here, we show that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the number of SAN cells. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells that links the number of cells with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to the regulation of the heart rate. This study provides insights into the mechanisms that regulate the number of cells and their activities in the SAN. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is a ubiquitous element in the environment, and its role in plant physiology has been debated for decades. Although Si is known to confer resistance to abiotic stresses, its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the insect herbivore Cnaphalocrocis medinalis (rice leaffolder) in a jasmonate (JA)-dependent manner. Our results suggest that Si may promote resistance against insect herbivores by priming JA-mediated defense responses. These findings provide insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may have implications for the use of Si in agriculture. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. The activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the metabolism of ether lipids in macrophages, which are the main immune cells in the body. The activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is also important for the signaling of the immune system.

Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the time constant of the adaptation process. The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenging task due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants with DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery and gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be of interest to the scientific community working on the delivery of biomolecules to plants.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the world’s lakes, but the role of small tributaries in driving coastal nutrient loading is poorly understood. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all tributaries of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. We found that the 6 largest of 235 tributaries accounted for ∼70% of the daily nitrogen and phosphorus delivered to Lake Michigan. However, small tributaries exhibited nutrient loads that were high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. Higher bioavailability of nutrients from small watersheds suggests greater potential to fuel algal blooms in coastal areas. Our findings reveal an underappreciated role that small streams may play in driving coastal eutrophication in large water bodies.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a strong forcing environment. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing.

The mechanisms underlying the effects of NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) on the brain are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs change the intrinsic properties of cortical microcircuits, which in turn alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We then show that these changes are sufficient to explain the effects of NMDAR-Abs on the EEG in a mouse model of NMDAR-Abs. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the effects of NMDAR-Abs on the brain and may help to explain the diverse range of EEG abnormalities observed in patients. This may also help to explain the effects of other antibodies on the brain. Finally, these findings may also help to explain the effects of other antibodies on the brain.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2 million y. The cause of this warming is unknown, but it is likely due to a combination of natural and anthropogenic forcings. To understand the causes of the current warming, it is important to understand the causes of past warming events. Here, we present a case study of a past warming event that occurred during a glacial period.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is essential for the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 evolutionarily conserved subunits. The function of the exocyst complex is to provide the force for the final step of exocytosis, which is the attachment of the nascent plasma membrane to the growing vesicle. Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex is a key component of sex differences in development and behavior. In many species, sex is determined by a single gene, but in others, multiple genes interact to determine sex. Here we show that the genetic basis of sex can produce a variety of outcomes, including the maintenance of a single sex determination allele, the introgression of a new sex determination allele, and the evolution of multiple sex determination alleles. These outcomes can have consequences for the evolution of sexual dimorphism and the maintenance of sex differences in behavior.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the presence of reactive oxygen species and photoproducts of vitamin A. These species are known to damage the retina, and the retina is the only organ in the body that contains iron. We sought to understand the role of iron in the retina and found that iron levels impact the retina in a manner that is dependent on the presence of vitamin A.

Predators are the key drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a central topic in ecology. In this study, we show that the evolution of predatory specialization in siphonophores is linked to the evolution of their prey.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The fossil record of the hominin hand between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is sparse, and the origin of the derived features of the modern human hand is poorly understood. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand from the Middle Pleistocene of Kenya that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the human hand.

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and thus one-carbon metabolism is a critical metabolic pathway. Here we show that the one-carbon donor pathway is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer.

Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change, and the loss of natural landscapes is a key contributor to the global nutrition crisis. This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated by the fragmentation of natural landscapes. The results have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, and the need to protect and restore natural landscapes to improve people’s diets and the environment.

Modern agriculture is a highly mechanised system, with the weight of farm machinery now exceeding that of the largest animals that walked Earth. This has led to the development of a new paradigm of soil compaction, with the weight of farm machinery now exceeding the safe mechanical limits of the soil. We show that this paradigm is not limited to modern agriculture, but is a global phenomenon, with subsoil compaction risk now affecting 20% of arable land. This alarming trend calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that the largest dinosaurs had the largest footprints. Our findings suggest that the ecological strategies of prehistoric animals may have been a key factor in the evolution of modern agriculture.
